div.p: Greetings and best wishes. If you are well, father, it is good; I am well. Your recent letters were most delightful to me for three reasons: first, because they are the most certain witnesses of your health; which health I so desire for you to be complete, that I ask nothing equally from God as that He may keep you safe for us, indeed for the church.

Secondly, because they were filled with new matters (which we read with great eagerness and reread with even greater pleasure), and thirdly, because they conveyed a most friendly and excellent gift joined with them, for which I give you the greatest thanks and will continue to do so as long as I live, perpetually. It provides me with much enlightenment. Praise be to God, who continually reveals His treasures to us more and more. I have nothing new, except that many brothers around us, who were previously sad and downcast, now lift their heads with great joy, many [Greek] who were previously somewhat arrogant now furrow their brows. May God be praised in all things.
My wife sends her greetings to you; greet all yours in my name. Farewell.
Biel/Bienne, 17th day before the Kalends of June, 1548.
To the most pious and learned man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his father, always to be greatly respected.
